heading: Introduction to Data Structures
subtitle: Foundation of Efficient Programming
introduction: A data structure is a way of organizing and storing data in a computer so that it can be accessed and modified efficiently. Data structures are fundamental building blocks of computer science and are crucial for developing high-performance software applications.
keyPoints: Data structures help in managing large amounts of data efficiently.
They are essential for designing efficient algorithms.
Common types include Arrays, Linked Lists, Stacks, Queues, Trees, and Graphs.
Choosing the right data structure can significantly impact program performance.
Understanding data structures is a prerequisite for competitive programming.
summary: Data structures are the backbone of computer science, enabling efficient storage and retrieval of data for complex operations. Mastering them is essential for any aspiring programmer.

heading: Arrays in Programming
subtitle: Linear Data Storage Made Simple
introduction: An array is a collection of elements stored at contiguous memory locations. It is the simplest and most widely used data structure. Arrays provide constant-time access to elements using their index.
keyPoints: Arrays store elements of the same data type in contiguous memory.
Access time is O(1) — the fastest among basic data structures.
Insertion and deletion require shifting elements, making them O(n).
Arrays have a fixed size once declared (in most languages).
Multi-dimensional arrays are used for matrices and grids.
summary: Arrays are fundamental data structures offering fast access but slower insertions and deletions. They're perfect for scenarios where you need quick element retrieval by index.

heading: Linked Lists
subtitle: Dynamic Data Chains
introduction: A linked list is a linear data structure where elements are stored in nodes. Each node contains data and a reference (pointer) to the next node in the sequence, allowing for dynamic memory allocation.
keyPoints: Linked lists use dynamic memory — they grow and shrink at runtime.
Insertion and deletion at the beginning are O(1) operations.
Accessing an element requires traversal, making it O(n).
Types include Singly, Doubly, and Circular linked lists.
No wasted memory — each node is allocated only when needed.
summary: Linked lists provide dynamic, flexible data storage with efficient insertions and deletions, making them ideal when the data size is unknown or changes frequently.

heading: Variables and Data Types in C
subtitle: Building Blocks of Every Program
introduction: Variables are named storage locations in memory that hold data. Data types define the kind of data a variable can store and the operations that can be performed on it.
keyPoints: Variables must be declared with a data type before use in C.
Primary data types: int, float, double, char.
Derived types include arrays, pointers, structures, and unions.
Type modifiers (short, long, signed, unsigned) alter storage size.
Constants are variables whose values cannot be changed after initialization.
summary: Variables and data types form the foundation of programming in C. Understanding them is essential for writing correct and efficient programs.

heading: Loops and Conditionals in C
subtitle: Controlling the Flow of Execution
introduction: Control flow statements determine the order in which instructions are executed. Conditionals allow branching, while loops enable repetition of code blocks.
keyPoints: if-else statements allow decision-making in programs.
switch-case provides multi-way branching on a single value.
for loops are best when the number of iterations is known.
while loops repeat as long as a condition remains true.
do-while guarantees at least one execution of the loop body.
summary: Loops and conditionals are essential control structures that give programs the ability to make decisions and repeat operations efficiently.
